item.title: NATO Is Sketching Out Plan to Meet Trump Call for 5% of GDP on Defense
item.description: NATO allies have started cobbling together an agreement to significantly boost defense spending in a way that may assuage US President Donald Trump’s demand to spend 5% of economic output on the military.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Selcan Hacaoglu

item.title: Trump Says US Exploring Normalizing Relations With Syria
item.description: President Donald Trump said the US would explore normalizing relations with Syria after the toppling of longtime autocrat Bashar al-Assad, doubling down on a pledge to lift sanctions against the country’s new government.
item.dc:creator: Sam Dagher, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump speaks during the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) Leaders’ Summit in Riyadh, on May 14.

item.title: US Legislators Seek End to Supersonic Flight Ban Over Land
item.description: A bipartisan group of US legislators are seeking to repeal regulations that ban civil jets from flying at supersonic speeds over land, in a change that would give startup Boom Technology Inc. a boost in its competition with potential rivals from China.
item.dc:creator: Kate Duffy

media:content.media:description: ENGLEWOOD, CO - NOVEMBER 15: The XB-1 aircraft sits in the hanger during the Demonstrator official unveiling at Boom Technologies on November 15, 2016 in Englewood, Colorado. (Photo by Tom Cooper/Getty Images for Boom Technology)

item.title: Tariffs Won’t Reindustrialize America. Here’s What Will
item.description: To revive manufacturing the US needs to borrow from China’s playbook.
item.dc:creator: Dan Wang, Ben Reinhardt

item.title: Trump’s Pause on China Tariffs Is Still a ‘Huge Nightmare’ for Small Businesses
item.description: President Donald Trump’s sudden move to lower tariffs on goods from China to 30% from 145% has thrown a lifeline to America’s small businesses who were running low on inventory — and cash.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran

item.title: Trump’s Plane-Dealing Diplomacy Takes Flight
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: Trump boards Air Force One on May 12 for his Middle East trip. Photographer: Win McNamee/Getty Images

item.title: Macron Calls Netanyahu ‘Shameful’ for Blocking Aid to Gaza
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron accused Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of “shameful” behavior in blocking humanitarian aid to Gaza, and called on the European Union to toughen its stance against the country.
item.dc:creator: Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, France's president, at the Elysee Palace in Paris, France, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Friedrich Merz travels to Paris and Warsaw on Wednesday on his first foreign trip as German chancellor, still reeling from a humiliating setback in Tuesday’s government transition that raised early questions about his leadership.

item.title: China Hosts Officials From Two Taiwanese Allies, Worrying Taipei
item.description: China’s hosting of envoys from two of Taiwan’s few remaining allies to an event has caused some concern in Taipei about possibly losing the support on the global stage, further isolating the democracy.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee

media:content.media:description: Jean-Victor Harvel Jean-Baptiste in Beijing, on May 13.

item.title: Thailand Upbeat About US Tariff Deal After Bessent Lauds Offers
item.description: Thailand expects a favorable outcome from talks with the Trump administration to avert the threat of a 36% tariff, after the Southeast Asian nation submitted a range of proposals to boost imports and allow greater market access for US goods.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: Romania’s Ultranationalist Presidential Hopeful Endorses Poland’s Nawrocki
item.description: Romanian ultranationalist George Simion attended an election rally of Polish opposition candidate Karol Nawrocki, seeking to resuscitate his political ally’s campaign before a presidential ballot on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski, Natalia Ojewska

media:content.media:description: George Simion

item.title: Iran Urges US to Show ‘More Realistic’ Approach at Nuclear Talks
item.description: Iran’s top nuclear negotiator said he hopes the US will show a “more realistic approach” at the next round of talks between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Patrick Sykes

media:content.media:description: Abbas Araghchi

item.title: Chinese Weapons Gain Credibility After Pakistan-India Conflict
item.description: The recent conflict between India and Pakistan is prompting a reassessment of Chinese weapons, challenging long-held perceptions of their inferiority to Western arms and sparking concern in places wary of Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Yian Lee, Sudhi Ranjan Sen

item.title: Thiam Plans Surprise Return as Leader of Ivory Coast Opposition
item.description: Tidjane Thiam, former chief executive officer of Credit Suisse Group AG, is running unopposed to lead Ivory Coast’s main opposition party just days after he resigned from the post, a maneuver aimed at bypassing a challenge to his eligibility to fill the position.
item.dc:creator: Kamailoudini Tagba

media:content.media:description: Tidjane Thiam

item.title: Odd Lots: Perry Mehrling on Trump’s Nixon Shock Echoes (Podcast)
item.description: There’s been a lot of talk recently about parallels between Donald Trump’s economic policies and the Nixon Shock of the early 1970s. That was when the former president took the dollar off the gold standard, introduced hefty tariffs, and pressured the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy. The moves sparked stagflation in the US and shook up the global monetary order. Now, given Trump’s determination to rebalance the US relationship with global trading partners and his criticism of the Fed, cou
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: India Signals Tougher US Trade Stance as China’s Tactic Pays Off
item.description: Indian officials said trade talks with the US remain on track, although there are signs that New Delhi is adopting a tougher approach in negotiations, following China’s defiance of US President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava, Ruchi Bhatia

media:content.media:description: A steel melt workshop in Jajpur, Odisha, India.

item.title: China Has ‘Price to Pay’ on Fentanyl Issue, Ex-US Envoy Says
item.description: The US has made it clear to China that failing to coordinate on the fentanyl issue comes at a cost, according to Nicholas Burns, America’s former ambassador to Beijing.
item.dc:creator: David Gura

media:content.media:description: Nicolas Burns, US ambassador to China, during a Bloomberg Television interview in Beijing, China, on Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023. The US's top diplomat in China called on President Xi Jinping's government to denounce terrorism by Hamas, citing Beijing's stance toward the group as yet another challenge in fraught ties between the world's biggest economies.

item.title: Saudi King-to-Be Marks Ascent With Gilded Welcome for Trump
item.description: When US President Donald Trump touched down in Riyadh he was greeted by a Saudi leader who was in every respect a king — except for his official title.
item.dc:creator: Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman at King Khalid International Airport on May 13.

item.title: Orban Seeks to Cut Funding to Hungary’s Independent NGOs, Media
item.description: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s party wants to choke off domestic funding to independent civil society organizations, in an increasingly aggressive crackdown that critics say is aimed at stopping a surging opposition less than a year before elections.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik

media:content.media:description: Viktor Orban at a political rally in Budapest, Hungary. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

item.title: Vietnam PM Orders Crackdown on Trade Fraud, Counterfeit Goods
item.description: Vietnam’s prime minister vowed to step up the fight against trade fraud, smuggling and counterfeit goods, as the nation seeks to address longstanding issues that have proved a sticking point in US tariff negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Xuan Quynh

media:content.media:description: Pham Minh Chinh

item.title: In Trump’s World, Jets Are Key to Unlocking Political Favors
item.description: President Donald Trump’s long-held fascination with the world of aviation is proving a useful tool for governments and companies seeking to win his favor.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump boards Air Force One at Joint Base Andrews, Maryland, on May 12.

item.title: Lula Says Brazil Unafraid of US Retaliation Over China Ties
item.description: Brazil’s President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva brushed off concern that the Trump administration would punish his country for building closer ties with China, after a state visit to Beijing that saw him sign more than 30 agreements.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping with Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in Beijing on May 13. Photographer: Tingshu Wang/POOL/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Merz Risks Coalition Spat With Call to Scrap EU Supply-Chain Law
item.description: Germany’s new chancellor, Friedrich Merz, reiterated a call for the European Union to scrap rules designed to make companies pursue sustainable policies in their supply chains, doubling down on a position that risks igniting conflict with his Social Democrat coalition partners.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz, right, with Kyriakos Mitsotakis in Berlin on May 13. Photographer: Odd Andersen/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Officials Resist Sharing How Migrants Were Tagged as Gangsters
item.description: The Trump administration doesn’t want to reveal just how it determined that some Venezuelans in the New York City area who it’s seeking to deport are members of the Tren de Aragua gang.
item.dc:creator: Robert Burnson

media:content.media:description: TECOLUCA, EL SALVADOR - MARCH 26: A prisoner with a tattoo with leg irons on stands as Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem tours the Terrorist Confinement Center (CECOT) on March 26, 2025 in Tecoluca, El Salvador. The Trump administration deported 238 alleged members of the Venezuelan criminal organizations 'Tren De Aragua' and Mara Salvatrucha with only 23 being members of the Mara. Nayib Bukele president of El Salvador announced that his government will receive the alleged members of the gang to be taken to CECOT. (Photo by Alex Brandon-Pool/Getty Images)

item.title: How Australia’s Housing Market Became So Out of Reach
item.description: Ballooning property prices and rents are causing serious housing affordability problems in Australia. So how bad is it? And how did it get to this point?
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey, Haidi Lun

item.title: Seven Days Will Decide If Britain’s Borders Are Open or Closed
item.description: The UK government’s paranoia about immigration must not derail the EU reset.
item.dc:creator: Rosa Prince

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, during a news conference ahead of the publication of the government's immigration white paper, in London, UK, on Monday, May 12, 2025. The UK will increase English-speaking requirements for migrants, and make it harder for them to stay in the country as part of efforts to rein in levels of net immigration that have touched records in recent years.

item.title: Hong Kong Rushes to Beef Up Security Law, Cementing China’s Grip
item.description: Hong Kong fast-tracked new national security rules that further consolidate Beijing’s control over the financial hub, with the changes taking effect immediately.
item.dc:creator: Alan Wong

media:content.media:description: The flag of China on a bridge in Hong Kong. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

item.title: Wall Street Sees Higher China Growth, Less Stimulus on US Truce
item.description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and other major banks boosted their forecasts for China’s 2025 economic growth, citing a better outlook for exports following the tariff truce with the US.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva, Yujing Liu

media:content.media:description: A worker loads bundles of goods onto a truck at an industrial park in Yiwu, Zhejiang Province, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: US Warns of Missile Threats That Trump’s Golden Dome May Face
item.description: China may within a decade possess scores of orbiting missiles with nuclear payloads capable of reaching the US with much shorter flight times than traditional intercontinental ballistic missiles, the Defense Intelligence Agency said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - MAY 12: White House Chief of Staff Susie Wiles looks on from behind a chart on the Golden Dome missile defense system as U.S. President Donald Trump speaks during a press conference in the Roosevelt Room of the White House on May 12, 2025, in Washington, DC. During the event, President Trump signed an executive order aimed at reducing the cost of prescription drugs and pharmaceuticals by 30% to 80%. (Photo by Andrew Harnik/Getty Images)

item.title: Bolivia President Arce Declines Candidacy, Calls for Left-Wing Unity
item.description: Bolivia’s President Luis Arce dropped his pursuit of reelection, calling for candidate Andronico Rodriguez to unite leftists ahead of the August vote and fend off a challenge from the right.
item.dc:creator: Sergio Mendoza

media:content.media:description: Luis Arce Photographer: Manuel Seoane/Bloomberg

item.title: Peru Prime Minister Resigns After Backlash From Cabinet Reshuffle
item.description: Peru’s prime minister resigned on Tuesday evening after a last-ditch attempt at a cabinet reshuffle did not placate opposition lawmakers who demanded his ouster.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun

media:content.media:description: Gustavo Adrianzen in 2024.
